SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 4 and 6 and Division 3.a (North Sea Rockall and West of Scotland kagerrak and Kattegat)
Description:
White anglerfish (Lophius piscatorius) and black anglerfish (L. budegassa) are two closely related species. White anglerfish occur throughout the north-east Atlantic. They are most abundant at depths of 200-800m but also occur in coastal waters. Black anglerfish occur from the north of Scotland to the west of Africa and are mainly found offshore between 200 and 500m depth. White anglerfish are relatively more abundant in northern areas while black anglerfish are relatively more abundant in Biscay and further south as well as an area in the western Celtic Sea. Recent research suggests that the two species occasionally inter-breed to form hybrids.

Anglerfish are difficult to age but are known to be relatively fast-growing. Females grow larger than males and mature at larger sizes. There is no minimum landing size but EC 2406/96 established a minimum marketing size of 500 g gutted weight or 200 g tailed.

The population structure of anglerfish is poorly understood but genetic diversity within the species appears to be limited. Anglerfish can migrate hundreds of kilometres and the eggs and larvae are pelagic for up to 4 months, allowing them to be dispersed over large areas. Recruitment success varies strongly between years.

TAC2022: The annual landings of anglerfish by Irish vessels were approximately 4,500 tonnes in the last 3 years, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal fish species: the landings in 2021 were worth around &#8364 16 million.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6-8 (Celtic Seas English Channel and Bay of Biscay)
Description: Boarfish is a small, pelagic, plankton eating, shoaling species, found at depths of up to 600 m. The species is widely distributed from Norway to Senegal, including the Mediterranean and oceanic island waters, but mostly south of Ireland to north Spain. Boarfish recruit to the fishery around three to four years of age, although the maximum age of boarfish is about 30. Spawning occurs on the Celtic Sea shelf edge during June and July. Under optimal conditions, boarfish are capable of spawning over an extended period of time. Maturation occurs at 3.5 years, corresponding to a total length of approximately 10 cm. The maximum size of this species is about 18 cm. Boarfish does not appear to be an important prey species in the Celtic Sea area.
TAC2023: On average approximately 13,600 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels each year using mainly pelagic trawls between 2020 and 2022, most of which were caught in 7.h, 7.j and 7.b. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark being the only other significant participant. In 2022 landings were worth approximately &#8364 3.4 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2022: On average approximately 12,135 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels each year using mainly pelagic trawls between 2019 and 2021, most of which were caught in 7.h, 7.j and 7.b. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark being the only other significant participant. In 2021 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2.7 million for Irish vessels.
ICESAdvice2023: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches should be no more than 27 349 tonnes in each of the years 2024 and 2025.
ICESAdvice2022: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches should be no more than 22 791 tonnes in each of the years 2022 and 2023.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.e-k & 7b,c (eastern English Channel and southern Celtic Seas)
Description:
Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) are widely distributed on both sides of the north Atlantic. In the NE Atlantic they occur from Norway to the Bay of Biscay.

Cod around Ireland are very fast growing and attain lengths in excess of 35cm in the first year and over 90cm as adults. About 50% of individuals are mature at 2 years and virtually 100% are mature by 3 years of age. Juveniles are more commonly found from 30 to 80m, mainly on rocky bottoms. Their diet consists of benthic animals, crustaceans and small fish. Fish become more prevalent in the diet in older cod. Once mature an adult female can produce over 2 million eggs.
TAC2023: On average 530 tonnes of cod were caught and landed annually in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2020 and 2022, 48% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2022 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1.9 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2022: On average 611 tonnes of cod were caught and landed annually in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2019 and 2021, 45% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2021 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1.6 million for Irish vessels.

Description: Horse mackerel is a widely-distributed pelagic species, sometimes regarded as semipelagic as they are often found near the seabed. They are a relatively long lived species that can live for more than 26 years. Large fluctuations in year class strength are a feature of horse mackerel stocks. Maturity is reached between the ages of 2 and 4. The western stock spawns in the Celtic Sea in June, followed by a northerly feeding migration. The stock may enter the North Sea from the north with abundance associated with the influx of Atlantic water. The return migration takes place in late autumn. Juveniles are pelagic feeders while larger individuals feed closer to the bottom, mainly on 0-group fish.

Description:
Megrim (Lepidorhombus whiffiagonis) and four-spot megrim (L. boscii) are two closely related flatfish species. L. whiffiagonis occurs throughout the north-east Atlantic while L. boscii occurs from the Mediterranean up to the Faroe Islands. Both species occur from inshore waters up to depths of around 800m but L. whiffiagonis are most abundant around 100-300m while L. boscii are most abundant around 200-600m. Irish landings are nearly exclusively L. whiffiagonis.

Adult megrim feed on small demersal fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. Megrim are relatively slow growing and long-lived. They spawn around January-March. Females grow larger, mature later and live longer than males. Females mature around 22cm; the minimum conservation reference size is 20cm.

Megrim (Lepidorhombus whiffiagonis) and four-spot megrim (L. boscii) are two closely related flatfish species. L. whiffiagonis occurs throughout the north-east Atlantic while L. boscii occurs from the Mediterranean up to the Faroe Islands. Both species occur from inshore waters up to depths of around 800m but L. whiffiagonis are most abundant around 100-300m while L. boscii are most abundant around 200-600m. Irish landings are nearly exclusively L. whiffiagonis.

Adult megrim feed on small demersal fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. Megrim are relatively slow growing and long-lived. They spawn around January-March. Females grow larger, mature later and live longer than males. Females mature around 22cm; the minimum conservation reference size is 20cm.

SpeciesByDiv: Division 7.a (Irish Sea)
Description:
Black sole (also called Dover sole) are flat fish which lie buried on sandy or muddy seabeds. They feed primarily at night on small crustaceans, worms and bivalve molluscs. In common with many flatfish, sole are fast growing as juveniles, slowing down as they mature. Females grow larger than the males. They can reach lengths of up to 70cm or weights of up to 3kg. Sole are quite solitary marine and estuarine fish, and the local environment may contribute to variable growth rates.

Females reach maturity at around 3 years when they are around 25-30cm long. An average mature female can produce in the region of 150,000 - 200,000 eggs a year. They spawn in spring and early summer. Juveniles (<3 years) are found in coastal nurseries before they move in to deeper waters.
TAC2023: The annual landings of sole by Irish vessels were approximately 204 tonnes in the last 3 years, 33% of which were caught in 7.a. In 2022 landings were worth around &#8364 2.0 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2022: The annual landings of sole by Irish vessels were approximately 208 tonnes in the last 3 years, 30% of which were caught in 7.a. In 2021 landings were worth around &#8364 3.2 million for Irish vessels.

ICESAdvice2022: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2023 should be no more than 605 tonnes.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 1-8 and 14 and Division 9.a (the Northeast Atlantic and adjacent waters)
Description: The Atlantic Mackerel is a widely distributed, migratory pelagic fish that inhabits much of the north-eastern Atlantic shelf. It is streamlined and fast swimming, forming dense shoals when migrating to spawning grounds to the south and west of Ireland. Spawning takes place between February and July after which they migrate north, disperse and feed. Diet depends on season but consists mainly of zooplankton and juvenile fish. Juvenile mackerel grow rapidly and reach 30cm after 2 years at which point more than half are mature. The majority of mackerel caught are between 4 and 8 years of age with individuals older than 15 rare.
TAC2023: On average, approximately 62,500 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels between 2020 and 2022, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a, 6.a and 7.b. It is the most valuable pelagic stock to Ireland worth approximately &#8364 78.4 million euros in 2022.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b-c (West of Ireland)
Description:
Plaice (Pleuronectes platessa) are found throughout the Atlantic coast of Europe and in the western Mediterranean. They are usually found in waters less than 100m depth. Older fish are found in deeper water. Plaice are most commonly found on sandy, muddy or gravel bottom. Small fish are found in intertidal areas and there is evidence to suggest homing behaviour.

Spawning occurs off the bottom from February to April and is dependent on water temperature. Males reach maturity between 2 and 6 years, and females between 3 and 7 years, with age at maturity again being dependent on water temperature. Young plaice feed on small worms and shrimp. As they grow their diet becomes more varied and they eat small crustaceans, crabs, mussels, scallops and shrimp.
TAC2023: Approximately 260 tonnes of plaice were annually caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2020 and 2022, nearly 42% of which was caught in 7.a. In 2022 landings were worth approximately &#8364 600,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2022: Approximately 300 tonnes of plaice were annually caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2019 and 2021, nearly 60% of which was caught in 7.a. In 2021 landings were worth approximately &#8364 550,000 for Irish vessels.
ICESAdvice2023: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings should be no more than 15 tonnes in each of the years 2024, 2025, and 2026.
ICESAdvice2022: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings should be no more than 19 tonnes in each of the years 2021, 2022, and 2023. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches.

Description:
Saithe is a large gadoid reaching maximum size of 130cm. It is a cold-water species distributed throughout the northern Atlantic. Saithe live in shoals, with juveniles occurring mostly in coastal waters while older fish move to deeper waters. Description:
Pollack is a benthopelagic gadoid, occuring thoughout the north-east Atlantic, mainly over hard/rocky bottom. Pollack usually occur at 40-100m depth but are found down to 200m. Young pollack occur mostly inshore while older fish move to deeper waters.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 6.a 7.b and 7.j (West of Scotland West of Ireland eastern part of southwest of Ireland)
Description:
Found distributed in coastal waters throughout the north-west Atlantic, European sea bass is a marine member of the Order Perciformes. The species is relatively long lived, attaining up to 25 years of age, and is slow to reach sexual maturity taking between 4 to 7 years. The life cycle of the species begins with planktonic larvae being dispersed among suitable inshore nursery locations. Juveniles remain near these locations until they begin the shoal up as adolescents at approximately 3 to 4 years old. It is believed that most adults spend summer months foraging in inshore water before migrating to deeper, warmer offshore waters during winter/spring periods. Spawning is believed to originate from a combination of offshore aggregations of sexually mature adults in addition to local inshore spawning events.

Telemetry research has identified significant inshore site fidelity in sea bass in Irish waters. There is also evidence of long scale migration (>100km) with fish tagged in Irish waters subsequently being recaptured in British coastal waters.
TAC2023:
Since 1990, there has been a ban on commercial fishing of sea bass by Irish vessels (Bass Conservation of Stocks Order, 1990). As a result, reported landings from Irish waters are relatively low. Recreational catches of sea bass are also strictly controlled and fall under the remit of Inland Fisheries Ireland.

Stock Interconnectivity

With no commercial landings for sea bass permitted by Irish vessels, insights into their distribution and behaviour are based on targeted biological sampling and telemetry studies. Previous research assumed that sea bass stocks in Irish waters were separate to that of other jurisdictions and the stock was managed as such. However, returns of tagged fish in conjunction with data collected from pop-off satellite archival tags (PSATs) used on sea bass in Irish waters show a notable level of migration to and from British waters. This new information is crucial for managing the sustainable recovery of the species here.
TAC2022:
Though distributed around the Irish coast, sea bass are primarily concentrated along the southern coast of divisions 7.j, 7.g. and 7.a. During colder periods, adult sea bass aggregate in shoals offshore to feed. Marine Institute research surveys have found a relatively clustered distribution of sea bass in the eastern Celtic Sea, particularly during the late autumn/early winter period.

Irish Landings and Fishery

Since 1990, there has been a ban on commercial fishing of sea bass by Irish vessels (Bass Conservation of Stocks Order, 1990). As a result, reported landings from Irish waters are relatively low. Recreational catches of sea bass are also strictly controlled.

Recent Research

The Marine Institute investigated the impact of water temperature and salinity on the behaviour and distribution of European sea bass within the Celtic Sea and Irish Sea regions using of biotelemetry (electronic tags to track fish movements). The Sea bass which were tagged were found to have wide range of movement behaviours along the Irish coastline. While many fish did show evidence of small home ranges (i.e. travelling <10km from where they were originally tagged), some individuals were observed to undertake considerable migrations (>450km).

ICES cannot quantify total catches. Note: This advice sheet is abbreviated due to the COVID-19 disruption. The previous advice issued for 2018-2020 can be found in the relevant year filters.

Description: Albacore is a medium sized, pelagic fish found offshore, in surface and mid waters between 14 &deg and 21 &deg Celsius. It is found from the Azores and Canaries north to Ireland, and westwards to the central USA. Separate stocks occur in the south Atlantic and the Mediterranean. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1, with maximum age of 15 years. Maturation occurs at 5 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately 90 cm, and maximum size is 128 cm. Juveniles migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters. Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea. Spawning ensues from April to September.

SpeciesByDiv: East Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea
Description: Bluefin tuna is the largest tuna, and one of the largest fish of all. It is a pelagic, fish-eating species, found from the surface to depths of up to 1,000 m, and in temperatures from 3&deg to 30&deg Celsius. It is found throughout the Mediterranean and north Atlantic extending to the very cold waters off Norway. A separate stock occurs in the western north Atlantic. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1, with maximum age of at least 20 years. Maturation occurs at 4 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately 115 cm, and maximum size is 400 cm. Juveniles migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters. Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea, and in the Mediterranean Sea. Spawning occurs from May to June, but individuals may only spawn every 2-3 years. Bluefin tuna are highly opportunistic predators that feed primarily on schooling fish. While they do eat pelagic shoaling fish such as herring and mackerel, there is no evidence that they specifically target them.
TAC2023: Ireland has no directed fishery for bluefin tuna. In 2022, 20 t of bluefin tuna were caught and landed by Irish vessels as bycatch (mainly in the albacore fishery) for which there is a minor quota. In 2022 the value of the catch of bluefin tuna was worth approximately &#8364 168,000.

Description: Sprat is a pelagic schooling fish usually found inshore, with juveniles sometimes found in estuaries. The species is widely distributed from Morocco to the South of Norway and four different stocks are identified in European waters. ICES has considered sprat in the Celtic Seas Ecoregion (ICES Divisions 6 and 7 excluding 7.d & 7.e) to be one stock since 2011. There is work ongoing to investigate stock structure and dynamics within the area. Sprat perform seasonal migrations between winter-feeding and summer spawning grounds as well as diel vertical migrations. Sprat reach a total length of 18 cm, size-at-maturity has been estimated at 10.1 cm and is highly variable between areas. Spawning occurs in shallow waters (10-20 m) and egg production ranges 6,000-14,000. There is currently no evidence of spawning site fidelity (homing). European sprat is an important species in the trophic web as it links between zooplankton and top predators (fish, birds and marine mammals).
